awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CubeSat Ideas Lab: Space Weather Atmospheric Reconfigurable Multiscale Experiment (SWARM-EX) CubeSats
awd_abstract_narration:
CubeSats are miniaturized, low-weight, low-cost satellites.  Due to these properties, constellations of 10s-100s of CubeSats with specialized instruments for studying the space environment provide a new exciting opportunity to understand and predict space weather.  The Space Weather Atmospheric Reconfigurable Multiscale Experiment (SWARM-EX) project provides an important step in the advancement of designing and building CubeSat constellations for space weather.  SWARM-EX will consist of three identical CubeSats with novel technologies for radio communications between satellites, onboard propulsion, advanced data downlinks, and autonomous operations within the constellation.  Each satellite will measure ionized and neutral gases in the Earth's upper atmosphere, studying structures seen near the equator.  The SWARM-EX mission uniquely fosters opportunities for STEM education and enables a platform for public outreach.  SWARM-EX will establish the first Intercollegiate CubeSat Mentoring Program - partnering institutions that have established CubeSat programs with new programs to create long-term, project-based learning environments across the nation.  Teaching, training, and learning will also be advanced through the inclusion of multiple graduate students, and undergraduate students from the six geographically distributed university programs involved in SWARM-EX.  This project resulted from the Ideas Lab: Cross-cutting Initiative in CubeSat Innovations, an interdisciplinary program supported by Geosciences, Engineering, and Computer and Information Science and Engineering Directorates.

SWARM-EX is a bold step towards addressing outstanding aeronomy questions achieved through a global constellation of CubeSat swarms making in-situ ionospheric and thermospheric measurements between 300 and 600 km altitude.  The CubeSats in each swarm will range in separation from 1 to 1000 km and this separation will be controlled by a combination of differential drag and onboard propulsion. A pathfinder mission, supported by this project will use 3 identical CubeSats to demonstrate the SWARM-EX key technologies and address scientific questions related to the evolution of the equatorial ionization anomaly (EIA) and equatorial thermospheric anomaly (ETA).  The specific aeronomy questions are 1) How persistent and correlated are the plasma density and neutral oxygen in EIA and ETA features?; 2) Over what timescales, less than 90 minutes, do we observe changes in EIA/ETA properties due to non-migrating tides and geomagnetic activity?  These CubeSats will demonstrate novel technology including RF cross-links, propulsion, CDMA X-band data downlinks and on-board autonomy.  Additionally, each CubeSat will include an atomic oxygen sensor and Langmuir Probe thus making the measurements required to answer the proposed science questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
SWARM-EX Autonomous Guidance, Navigation, and Control (SWAG)

PI: Prof. Simone D’Amico, Stanford University

Space weather results from the complex interaction between the Sun’s ejecta and Earth’s magnetic field. The resulting disturbances and solar radiation storms may disrupt or damage electronics in exposed systems, including the Earth’s electrical grid and satellites that are critical for communications, internet, global navigation, remote sensing, weather monitoring and prediction, and national security missions among others. Since most of the satellites we rely upon operate in low Earth orbit (LEO), the region above Earth’s surface with an altitude less than 2,000 kilometers, it is even more important to gain a better understanding of the LEO environment which is dynamic and constantly changing in response to solar activity.

The Space Weather Atmospheric Reconfigurable Multiscale Experiment (SWARM-EX) provides a low-cost opportunity to answer several key questions about the LEO environment by employing three propulsive CubeSats (small spacecraft made of approximately 10x10x10 centimeter units) equipped with scientific instruments to make in-situ measurements of atomic oxygen, plasma, and ultimately density in the upper layers of the atmosphere. In order to accomplish this, the SWARM-EX CubeSats shall be able to control the orbital motion relative to one another to acquire and maintain several specific formation geometries over the mission lifetime with the desired level of accuracy and agility. Broadly, this capability is referred to as Guidance, Navigation, and Control (GNC) for multiple spacecraft, and is the focus of this award.

The research conducted in this award has resulted in the development of a novel GNC system for spacecraft swarms called the SWARM-EX Autonomous Guidance, Navigation, and Control (SWAG) system, to be deployed on the SWARM-EX mission  Although SWAG has been designed to meet the requirements of the SWARM-EX mission, it is generally applicable to CubeSat swarms and could enable the accomplishment of unprecedented scientific objectives by these low-cost spacecraft. SWAG embeds autonomous GNC algorithms directly into a flight-ready software and is accompanied by several contributions to the state of the art:

(1) a novel reduced-order GNC model that enables orbit design of general spacecraft swarm missions at an early stage of the project lifecycle;

(2) a distributed swarm navigation methodology that enables the concurrent estimation of spacecraft orbits and environmental parameters; and

(3) a distributed swarm control methodology that optimally combines orbit maneuvers based on propulsion (by expelling cold gas at high speed) and based on atmospheric drag (through modulation of the cross-sectional area) into a novel hybrid approach.

SWAG integrates these new features while ensuring the safety of the swarm in terms of collision avoidance and providing the needed flexibility to hand over control to the ground when the spacecraft are beyond the range of their internal communication network.

The process of mission and orbit design for spacecraft swarms is complicated by the need to consider relative orbit configuration, collision avoidance, and fuel balancing between partner spacecraft. This computationally expensive and time-consuming process is eased by the development of a novel reduced-order model that is able to use simplified models for the relative orbit dynamics experienced by spacecraft swarms to rapidly provide key outputs to mission designers, including propellant consumption and minimum separation distances between spacecraft.

In order to achieve the commanded desired relative orbit configurations, spacecraft must be capable of accurately determining their position and velocity with respect to their partners, as well as predicting where they will be in the future. The first major component of SWAG achieves this through a distributed swarm navigation methodology that is able to accurately estimate the absolute and relative orbits, in addition to key parameters related to the upper atmosphere environment that the spacecraft encounter.

The accomplishment of the SWARM-EX science mission requires spacecraft to transition from/to small inter-spacecraft separations (for cross-satellite instrument calibration) to/from extremely large separations (for space weather data collection). The second major component of SWAG enables this transition with a novel hybrid control architecture, regulating the difference in atmospheric drag between spacecraft to supplement the propulsive relative orbit control at negligible cost. The architecture utilizes a provably-optimal, closed-form hybrid solver, accomplishing both on-board roto-translational maneuver planning, that provides asymptotically stable convergence over long reconfigurations despite the frequent, large variations in atmospheric drag magnitude found in LEO.

Besides enabling SWARM-EX, this project has led to the conception, design, build, and testing of a novel general purpose GNC system for CubeSat swarms. In addition, this project has enabled four graduate students and one postdoctoral scholar to receive training in mission design, astrodynamics, spacecraft GNC, flight software development and testing. Finally, this project has produced six peer-reviewed publications, with several more publications currently in progress.
